titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

p.hi: The Archdeacon and I motored to Colwall, & there discussed with D
Harris the question of a resident curate for Upper Colwall. We went to the latter, & admired the noble view of the Malvern Hills. Then we went to Coddington, & had tea with old M

Bulkeley & his wife. He agrees that it would be desirable to unite Coddington and Bosbury. As both livings are in my gift it ought not to be impossible to do this. On the return journey to Hereford, as we passed through Tupsley, the car swerving to avoid a bicycle struck an elderly man. We stopped and picked him up. He seemed more shaken than hurt, so we carried him in to D
Morris, & I sent back the car to carry him home. I have reason for thankfulness that he was not killed outright.
Herbert Gratton, a Baptist military chaplain, who has recently served in Mesopotamia, arrived to dine and sleep.
He is desirous of receiving Ordination
in the Church of England, but he is 38, and has had no academic education whatever.
